newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: TAIWANESE DEFENCE MINISTER VISITS CZECH REPUBLIC.
newsitem.headline: TAIWANESE DEFENCE MINISTER VISITS CZECH REPUBLIC.

text.p: PRAGUE, Nov 15 (Rauter) - Taiwanese Defence Minister Chiang Chung-ling is in the Czech Republic, the Foreign Ministry said on Friday, in the latest in a series of high-level Taipei visits even though Prague recognises only China.
"It is true the minister is here," said Karel Boruvka, a Foreign Ministry spokesman. "It is (part of) his visit to Central Europe, but it is purely a private visit."
Boruvka told Reuters he did not know how long Chiang would stay in Prague nor where is he to leave for.
Although the Czech Republic has no diplomatic relations with Taiwan, the government defends the country's right to do business with the island state which China regards as a renegade province.
A number of Czech companies export arms although sales abroad have to be approved by several government departments including the Foreign Ministry.
Boruvka denied that government officials would meet Chiang but made no direct comment on suggestions that he was in the Czech Republic to buy weapons.
"He will not meet any Czech official. Whether he has got meetings with companies, I do not know," he said.
An official at the Taipei Business Chamber in Prague said he had no information about Chiang's visit.
Czech media have reported that Taiwan is interested in cooperating with troubled aircraft maker Aero Vodochody, which makes military trainers, albeit to build small business jets.

Last year Beijing reacted angrily when Taiwanese Premier Lien Chan visited the Czech Republic for a supposedly private but highly-publicised visit which included talks with President Vaclav Havel and Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus.
Havel also irritated China by expressing regret that Taiwan was not a member of the United Nations.

Taiwanese Economics Minister Chiang Pin-kung met government officials in Prague last year, announcing amid great fanfare a $100 million industrial park would be opened in the western city of Plzen this year. So far nothing has materialised.
Relations with Beijing improved in April this year when Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen visited Prague.
The Czech Defence Ministry also denied any contact with the Taiwanese defence minister. "Nobody contacted us, nobody talked to us, nobody demanded anything," said spokesman Vaclav Tichy.
A Trade and Industry Ministry official also said Chiang's visit was news to him.
